3ἔζησεν [ἔτη ..]
4μ<ῆ>νας ❦ [..]
5ἡμ[έρας ..]

Very regular neat v-cut letters. The text is centred on the stone. Note the use of horizontal lines/dashes between the name and patronym of the officials. Sigma is four bar and open; Pi has short second vertical; omicron and omega are small, the latter closed.
Probably Hieronian in date, given the letter forms and the content.

1Λισσίας Νεμηνίου
Inscription recording the neaniskoi of the gymnasium

The text fills the face available below the cornice (and seems likely to have continued below), with probably a consistent left margin, but a less regular right margin, and some cramping in order to fit words/phrases to the line (as e.g. in line 1).

The letters are mostly regular with a fairly square module and terminal points to the strokes rather than serifs. Alpha has broken cross-bar; epsilon has nearly equal bars; zeta in the form of an I with broad crossbars; kappa has short arms; mu has sloping outer strokes and half-height mid-strokes; omicron is nearly full-size, and consistently has a central dot (in lines 2 and 3 appears to have a line underneath); rho has rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes, and the mid-strokes extend almost the full width; phi is standard height, elliptical; omega is consistently a closed circle (without the central dot of omicron), sometimes on the baseline, sometimes traversed by the line.
Photo J. Prag, 29.06.2016, with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Cordiano, 1997, La ginnasiarchia nelle "poleis" dell'occidente mediterraneo antico

6Ἀγαθα̣ρ̣ [. 5-7.].σο [. 3-5.] ου

Wide, slightly irregular in size v-cut letters: alpha wide with straight bar; epsilon has shorter middle bar; omicron is full size; pi has equal length hastae; omega is rhomboid and almost closed; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes, and slight tendency to curvature in line 2.

Statue of Demeter with inscribed base

The text is engraved over six lines on a flat field 30.3 cm wide and 12-13 cm
                                        high. The left and right sides of this field are cut smooth, the upper and lower
                                        edges are uneven. The lower right and left corners are slightly damaged. The
                                        inscription is intact apart from damage to the middle of line 1 where the upper
                                        front edge of the plinth has been damaged. There is a clear vacat to the bottom
                                        and right of the text. The first line is larger and extends to left and right of
                                        the rest of the text. Lines 2-6 have a consistent left margin.

Alpha has broken bar; epsilon and sigma are lunate; omega is lightly but clearly
                                    rhomboid; omicron is smaller than the other letters and sits above the line; phi is
                                    extended well above and below the line.
Photo J. Prag with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

3[λ]άς
Text is set out over six lines within a panel of 26 x 21 cm in the form of a tabula ansata

Lunate omega, sigma and epsilon; alpha, lamda and delta have extended upper strokes; mu appears in two forms on line 2, typical later form with tall upper strokes and at line end a small rounded form mid-line; xsi on line 4 is formed of two horizontals with a detached curved stroke between. The repetition of the deceased's name on line 3 is marked off by a large comma-shaped interpunct.
later 3rd century CE (Ferrua on letter forms)
Photo J.Prag: Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

The inscription is incised in a plain area of the body of the altar, approximately half-way up, next to the remains of a handle. It is unclear whether the text was incised before or after firing (no statement in publication, and photograph not sufficient.
